instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not video
threads.message:
computer turns on, no video, no usb activity, not external video.these measurements

PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET=8.6
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV_L</SIGNAL>=8.3v
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>=0v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>=0v
<SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>=0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not video
threads.message:
Why wasting time checking backlight circuit, if don't get image, nor USB activity?

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes on?
Any history fault?
Did you try known good BIOS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not video
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>=3.3V
Any history fault? A LITTLE HUMIDITY BOARD, CHANGE <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>,<RESISTOR>R1931</RESISTOR>
Did you try known good BIOS? YES
